newsitem.title: INDIA: India business not patriotic like Chinese, PM says.
newsitem.headline: India business not patriotic like Chinese, PM says.

text.p: Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda told Indian businessmen on Tuesday that they lacked the patriotism of their Chinese counterparts who had become key players in funding Beijing's economic reforms.
He told a meeting of the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FICCI) that of some $20 billion invested in China recently, 80 percent was funded by overseas Chinese.
"This cannot be said about Indians," he added.
Departing from his prepared speech, Deve Gowda questioned the commitment of businessmen to the country's welfare since independence from Britain in 1947.

"How much Indian money has been siphoned out since independence?" he asked. "I am not going to blame the previous prime ministers, the finance ministers and the government alone. Let us collectively work together for the country."
Deve Gowda told FICCI's 69th annual meeting that he would consider their request to remove a recently introduced minimum alternate tax on companies when the next year's budget is prepared.
But he said it would be unfair to blame the tax, among other issues cited as the cause for a slide in the country's capital markets.
"Too much sensational statistics is being fed in to suggest an economic slowdown," Deve Gowda said. "It is true that certain sectors have to improve but others have done reasonably well."
